comment: NOTIFICATION SQUAD: Where'd you want to see Natsuki and I travel to next?! We're hoping to do more of these excursions throughout 2021! And a special thanks to Sharla & Shiori from Tokyo Creative who came along on short notice to help us film our journey. They're lurking in the background throughout the video. I have to say the Tottori sand dunes exceeded my expectations, and I'd love to re-visit the region if not to explore, then certainly to shoot NATSUKI OF ARABIA. (ALSO stick around the for the outtakes right at the end of the video ğŸ˜‚).

I understand that bullet trains are a technology marvel, but for me, a train is only nice if it is not too fast, 100-140 kmh. I do not get it why being so fast you can't even see things can be called quality travelling. Maybe a reason I do not appreciate planes too much, even if I fly regularly. Night trains are beautiful memories when I was 6-23. The other thing I miss in modern trains is that you can't open windows. Also, all those superfast trains have no way of stopping for anything in time. I know Japanese trains are surprisingly safe, but still. I love the older trains that you can still feel, the cozy movements, the night stops, the change of scenery and climate.

The rooms seen in the video on the sleeper train for Japan are about the right size for the accommodations. The roomettes and suites on Amtrak are different in size and amenities that they offer. While quite a few of the standard roomettes on Amtrak share shower facilities, some include a private shower and separate bathroom facilities. In comparison, I would say that Amtrak roomettes are a little more spacious and the roomette packages offer breakfast and dinner included with the option of complimentary room service or dining in a special dining car. Another amenity that Amtrak offers for their roomette guests is a complimentary toiletries gift bag. The family suites on Amtrak are double the size of a roomette and offer the same meal packages as well as complimentary toiletries gift bags, including complimentary room service with the option to dine in a separate dining car. In comparison to the room that Chris stayed, in this video Amtrak's roomette is almost three times bigger than his room is. In fact, Natsuki's room in the video is the size of an Amtrak roomette, without a bathroom, nor included shower facility. The showers on Amtrak are amazing, you can get up to an hour of shower time using an Amtrak shower, due to their recirculating shower system. The solo accommodations shown on the Japanese sleeper train would normally be a utility closet and used for storing items. The room that Chris stayed in would normally be an Amtrak staff room housing two staff members, who while appreciative for a place to sleep would feel very cramped in them. The public coaches on an Amtrak train offer plush, comfortable seats which recline for sleeping in. Passengers in coach have a snack car which offers snacks for sale with no shower accommodations.

How long did it take you to get used to earplugs? I find it a really "disgusting" feeling and usually take them out after 5 minutes.

Â @Amar061Â  you don't have to force yourself to do something that others like, just be yourself. Also we shouldn't depend on any external gadget/object for sleep, it must come to us naturally without any external stimuli.

Â @Amar061Â  It's generally not a good idea to plug up your ears for extended periods of time, due to the ear wax build up and heightened risk of ear infection. So you are probably not missing out ğŸ˜Š

Â @Amar061Â  I don't use ear plugs but I have a comfortable pair of noise canceling headphones as well as 2 soft pillows. With the right cushioning I don't really feel the headphones and my ear canal isn't blocked
Â @Amar061Â  You get used to it, and Iâ€™ve had earwax buildup over time, but Iâ€™d trade wax over many, many nights of restful sleep over being an insomniac!

Â @ArjunSharma-gy1eqÂ   Thank you! Of course, that is self-understood, but in the odd moments when there is, because of special circumstances, just too much noise and huge noise-canelling earphones seem unpractical, ear plugs would be nice... if they didn't feel that disgusting in my ear.

Â @Khenfu_CakeÂ  Yup, and I only ever needed them maybe 4 times in my life because of special circumstances, but each time I had to take them out after 5 minutes, because it just felt disgusting and itchy having them in my ears, so I wondered if I used them incorrectly, since a lot of people seem to be using them without issues. Thanks!
Â @ANJK-eu7xfÂ  Yup, definitely, but sometimes the noises you want to plug out are overwhelming! Luckily for me, not often.
Â @hinatahyuuga120Â  Thats really nice. Care to share how you arrange your cushioning so as not to feel the headphones?
Â @oldschoolm8Â  Yup, I agree. Good sleep > nearly anything else.

Â @Amar061Â  I actully have 3 ways I sleep since I'm a side sleeper. I either use a thin pillow and a neck pillow for travel. I have pericings to so I sleep like this regularly. I have a pillow that actully has a carved out section designed for like ears, or glasses or headphones, my comfy pillow has one. And if those are to much for me I wrap up a soft blanket making a wide doughnut and then sleep on that. If you didn't know, Japan is the only country granted unilateral protection status. Any attack on Japan, is by treaty, promised to be honored as an attack on America. Mostly because we felt incredibly guilty about the bombs. But also, a few decades later, the US came in and saved Japan's tanking economy, probably the only time we prevented Communism from taking root without waging war.  Something else I always find odd. My father's family is from Japan (moved post-Korean war but parents both in WWII), and most older Japanese people in America will say, "no Japanese-American, I am American." Almost as if they subconsciously consider themselves as having abandoned Japan, and so there is no going back. That or they're dedicated to their decision.  Unfortunately, US demands post-war also ended up being a direct cause of the current imperial succession crisis they've been debating for two decades. I think maybe we could partially rescind that abolition of a noble class. No extra privileges, but sort of like knighting people in England, grant people the title for meritorious acts or Nobel-esque contributions to the country. Now you've solved the imperial succession issue without reinstituting an actual caste system AND you've given people a reason to do more for their country.

What's wrong with the Night Bus!?

I rode night trains in Europe, the cheapest class available, and it doesn't compare in the slightest to this. The rooms that I slept in were filled with two triple-bunk beds on either side, no shower. Occasionally passengers would come and go, so you better keep all your clothes on. Breakfast roll with jam and coffee in the morning. Thin blankets, no pillow (at least as far as I can recall, perhaps they were comically thin too, I remember resting my head on my jacket). That being said, the comfort of just being able to lie down is a blessing on a long travel.

Seeing as Japan has a fascination with English and American culutre, Britain or the United States of America would be good places. For the US I would look to New York or California. A few bigger cities in the two do have places like 'little tokyo' which is where Japanese migrants sort of set up shop so it would be a taste of home. But since they also in a rela big city you have access to tons of other culutres as well. I visit new york city frequently because my family is from there but I belive it is in queens you can find very authentic east Asian restaurants so you won't miss home to much while abroad.
Â @hinatahyuuga120Â   Oh nice  It is good for me to feel japan while abroad!! When i go abroad, i must miss sushi ()

Â @å¯Œå£«å±±é™å²¡ç©ºæ¸¯å¤§å¥½ãÂ  you can find sushi in a slot of places here. It often won't be nigiri. Some places do offer it as well as simple Maki and uramaki rolls. But for the most part the United States over complicates it, but leads to interesting taste profiles.
Â @hinatahyuuga120Â  yeah i know it I wanna try American sushi. Anyway I am glad to chat with you â˜ºï¸ It is good opportunity to output my English skills

Â @å¯Œå£«å±±é™å²¡ç©ºæ¸¯å¤§å¥½ãÂ  Los Angeles has a lot of good sushi! Some places are pretty authentic (especially south of LA). We have also have ramen, izakaya, robata, & shabu shabu. If you come to California, I suggest going to a dispensary (if that is something you'd like to try). We have very different views here on cannabis. For California, I recommend visiting San Diego, Big Sur, the Redwoods, San Francisco, Yosemite, Napa, Healdsburg (small town, but good wine and cheese!), & maybe Petaluma (smaller town, but I enjoyed it). Los Angeles is usually disappointing for tourism. I live around LA and it's nice for living, but places like Hollywood are not as interesting to see, and I'd actually say it's best not to even go there. Parts of downtown LA like Little Tokyo and the Arts District are ok. There is a good art museum called The Broad and the Disney Concert Hall for classical music. If you like other types of music, there are a LOT of places to see performances. Santa Monica is good for tourism. If you like architecture, then you may like to explore some of the neighborhoods or to do an architectural tour. As for the rest of the country, there is a lot of really fantastic nature to see. Obviously, there's also New York, Las Vegas, Seattle, New Orleans, Chicago, and more.

The whole getting woken by the announcements thing? TAKE EARPLUGS. Put your phone under your pillow with an alarm on vibrate - boom, problem solved! I do it all the time. When the only time off you get is so limited, people value getting to a vacation destination faster rather than enjoying the trip itself instead. For those who are interested in taking this train with JR Pass, I can confirm that you only need to pay for the room fee if you choose to stay in a room. The train fare will be included in the JR Pass. The train is a good choice for traveling from Osaka to Tokyo too(runs from 0:30 to 7:30), if you don't want to go all the way to Tottori. It saves you one night of hotel, and it's an unique experience. Highly recommended!(The shower cards will sell out fast so you need to go grab one as soon as you're on board. It's available from the vending machine on the train or from the conductor)

There is something romantic about sleeper trains. I think they still have their place in the world of high speed rail, for example if you want to arrive at your destination at 9 a.m. it's much easier to sleep on the way there than to take the bullet train at 6 a.m. Unfortunately here in Spain sleeper trains (called "tren hotel") are also a dying breed. I think the only one left is from Lisboa, Portugal to Madrid. Everyone who likes traveling by rail should experience an overnight train at least once.

I rode a sleeper train from Tokyo to Shimane (maybe the same line as you, just an earlier stop) when I was studying abroad. We did an internship there. It is the second least populated prefecture and the memory that sticks out the most is that everybody had the same name in the area I stayed in. They were all named Watanabe, so I couldn't call anybody by name. I just called them all Obaachan and Ojiichan (because 80% of the people were elderly). I also saw a 90 year old man climb a tree to get fruit for an old lady. It was an interesting experience and one reason I prefer inaka over the city.

In the German night train I used to frequently travel from Mannheim to a project in Kopenhagen (Denmark), there was also a shower in each upper cabin. Night trains are a really comfortable way to travel. Other then flying, with it's pad downs at security, the forced slalom course through the shopping areÃ¡ and it's limited cabin baggage and lack of leg space. Other then arriving annoyed and stressed at your destination, with a night train one arrives relaxed after a good night's sleep. Yes, it takes much longer, but it happens during the time one sleeps anyhow, so there is not really more time lost. But of course that night connection, starting in Switzerland, traveling S to N through all of Germany and ending in Denmark, got eventually canceled. I assume ppl want to be stressed nowadays. Ah, yes one more remark: That cabin hanger has a looped "hook" so it can not be used in a usual cloth cabin. That discourages people from stealing it as they can't use it. That is also the reason many hotels have non-standard hangers.

Growing up I visited the Sleeping Bear Dunes in Michigan regularly (maybe an hour drive from grandpa's abandoned farm, another awesome destination, but you can't go there, because it's ours (actually nobody's there, anybody could enter)) and it became more and more touristed as time went by, losing more of its magic. But sand dunes are so amazing and yet there's no way to record it properly on film, I've found. You just have to be there yourself.  And I've gotten poison ivy from the surrounding forest so many times. I always imagine it would help keep people out, but it's just me that's affected so heavily ğŸ˜‘ Anyway I notice a lot of Asian not-speaking-English tourists there and find myself wondering what similar places they have in their home countries. Tottori is 500-600 km west of Tokyo, not south of Tokyo.  If you travel 500 km south of Tokyo, you will find yourself swimming (or not) in very deep water, or maybe on one of the islands of the Izu archipelago, which are nonetheless part of Tokyo Prefecture, not Tottori. A simple glance at a map of Japan would tell you that there really isn't a lot south of Tokyo.  It is, however, a relatively easy mistake to make

It's ironic that sleeper trains are losing relevance in Japan while they're enjoying a resurgence in Europe. Thanks to operators like NightJet, an offshoot of OBB or Austrian State Railways, sleeper trains are now available to major cities throughout almost all of Central Europe, with a line recently opening between Brussels and Vienna with connections as far south as Sicily and as far east as Istanbul. And they're proving incredibly popular thanks to ticket costs less than half that of airlines and stations being located in or near the center of every major city.   But while public sleeper trains in Japan may be fading away, a new industry is emerging for so-called "Cruise Trains", ultra-luxury trains that offer scenic tours through parts of Japan. The point of these trains isn't so much to go anywhere, but to show off the sights to high class tourists, like a cruise ship on rails. One of the first and probably still the most famous is the Seven Stars of Kyushu, which meanders its way over about 6 days from Fukuoka throughout the Kyushu countryside. Even one former sleeper train, the Casseopeia, which once ran between Ueno and Hokkaido, is supposedly being converted into a cruise train.
